data.title: National Basketball Retired Players Association
data.meta_description: As a non-profit organization comprised of retired professional basketball players, the NBRPA Dallas Chapter’s mission is to unite our former players in collaboration with community partners to provide leadership enhancement, workplace readiness and basketball development to make a positive impact win those in need in North Texas.
data.text:
Willie Davis has served as the Dallas Chapter president since 2016. Davis was drafted in the 7th round of the 1968 NBA draft by the Chicago Bulls out of North Texas State University, where he was the Missouri Valley Conference’s Sophomore of the Year in 1964-65 after averaging 16.2 points and 12.7 rebounds.

Davis played professionally for CSE Toulous of the French League during the 1968-69 season, leading the league in scoring with 29.8 points per game. Davis then played in the American Basketball Association (ABA) during the 1970-71 season with the Texas Chapparals. Davis was inducted into the North Texas Athletics Hall of Fame in 1996.

Morlon Wiley played college basketball at Long Beach State, where he was a four-year starter for the 49ers. In 1988, he was an All-Big West Conference pick, and his leadership led to the school’s first NIT appearance. He was inducted into the 49ers’ Hall of Fame in 2005.

Wiley was a second round choice (46th overall) by Dallas in the 1988 NBA Draft, and played in 295 regular season games during his NBA career with Dallas, Orlando, San Antonio, Atlanta and Miami.

Wiley was a member of the inaugural Magic squad back in 1989-90 and was the first player ever signed by Orlando on June 29, 1989.

Cincy Powell played forward from at the University of Portland, and was selected by the St. Louis Hawks in the eighth round of the 1965 NBA Draft. Cincy would soon blossom while playing for the Dallas Chaparrals of the ABA, averaging 18.3 points and nine rebounds in his first season, and two years later he represented Dallas in the ABA All-Star Game. Cincy also spent time with theKentucky Colonels, Utah Stars and Virginia Squires, and finished his ABA career in 1975 with 9,746 total points.

On March 21, 2018, Basketball Hall-of-Famer Nancy Lieberman was named head coach of Power of the BIG3. She is the first woman ever to become head coach of a men’s professional team in any sport.

Lieberman has an unparalleled resume, including eight years of professional play in the Women’s Professional Basketball League and WNBA, eight years of professional coaching experience in the WNBA, NBA D-League (head coach of the Texas Legends, affiliate of the Dallas Mavericks) and NBA (Sacramento Kings assistant coach), and time as a broadcaster for ESPN and ABC. Lieberman also earned a silver medal at the 1976 Summer Olympics and a gold medal as a member of USA Basketball’s 1979 World Championship team.

Lieberman was named to three All-American teams while winning back-to-back AIAW National Championships at Old Dominion University. Nicknamed “Lady Magic,” she was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1996.

Sam Perkins grew up in New York before becoming a star at the University of North Carolina. He was a three-time college All-American, a 1982 NCAA champion, a teammate to future Hall of Famers James Worthy and Michael Jordan, and the 1984 USA Basketball Male Athlete of the Year.

Perkins was chosen as the fourth overall pick in the 1984 NBA draft by the Dallas Mavericks after his senior season and went on to have a successful 17-year career as a center and power forward. That same year, he co-captained the gold-medal winning U.S. Olympic basketball team and was named to the NBA All-Rookie First Team. In 2008, Perkins was inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame, and later named Vice President of Player Relations for the Indiana Pacers.

Ron Taylor focuses his practice on insurance and reinsurance matters. He gained vast experience as Vice President and Special Counsel for Business Development for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, a division of Health Care Service Corporation. In that role, Ron assisted with various aspects of sales and marketing, including establishing new business relationships and enhancing existing ones. Ron was General Counsel for BCBSTX for more than 20 years. He retired from the U.S. Army Reserve as a Lieutenant Colonel.

Ron is a mainstay of the Texas legal community, where, in addition to his current roles, he is a past board member of the Texas Association of Business and the Texas Association of Life and Health Insurers as well as the Texas Association of Health Plans and the North Texas Commission. Ron was also a member of the Dallas Citizens Council and is immediate past chairman of the board of the Richardson Chamber of Commerce. Ron’s community service commitment is notably reflected by his participation on the boards of charitable organizations, including Friends of Wednesday’s Child, Home for the Holidays, and the Dallas chapters of the American Heart Association and Children at Risk.

Stratton Horres is the Southwest regional managing partner for the law firm of Wilson, Esler, Moskowitz, Edeleman and Dicker LLP.

An accomplished litigator, Stratton has more than 35 years of experience and focuses his practice on commercial, product liability, health care, transportation and construction matters. He has handled insurance agents and brokers professional negligence cases and D&O matters. In addition, Stratton has represented financial institutions of all kinds. He has taken numerous jury and bench trials to verdict, and has successfully defended many verdicts on appeal. His trial and appellate practice encompasses state and federal courts across Texas and the Southwest region and throughout the United States.

Stratton frequently speaks to local and international audiences on a range of legal topics such as technology, health care and professional negligence, and is the author of numerous articles, including “Fire at Will” published in Texas Business magazine.

In support of the firm’s pro bono initiative, Stratton is also as chairman of the Northern Texas CHILDREN AT RISK advisory board and chairman of the Mothers Against Drunk Driving advisory board.

LaToyia Watkins Pierce is a Senior Claims Counsel with AXA XL Insurance Company in Dallas, Texas. LaToyia retains and manages outside counsel to defend professionals who are sued in courts, before regulatory bodies, and in arbitrations across the country. She oversees cases involving errors and omissions insurance, miscellaneous professional liability insurance and other forms of insurance coverage. LaToyia actively participates in all aspects of litigation and practice and risk management for insureds and their counsel.

Prior to joining AXA XL, LaToyia had more than 10 years of experience handling complex and diverse litigation, representing individuals, companies and professionals. Her practice was devoted primarily to commercial litigation and professional malpractice, in which she defended claims for broker-dealers, investment advisers, insurance agents, lawyers and real estate professionals, among others. She handled cases involving errors and omissions insurance and provided all associated services, including litigation and regulatory investigations. She often counseled clients on risk avoidance issues and was called upon regularly to provide in-house continuing education seminars. LaToyia has successfully settled and tried cases in state and federal court as well as in arbitration hearings before FINRA panels.

LaToyia holds a J.D. from Southern Methodist University Dedman School of Law in Dallas, Texas, an M.B.A. from the University of Texas at Dallas in Richardson, Texas, and a B.S. in Economics from Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas. In addition to the NBRPA Dallas Chapter advisory board, LaToyia also serves on the school board for Legacy the School of Sport Sciences in Houston and the board for Children at Risk.

Tom Fireoved is the the founder and president of Franchise Sports & Entertainment, a full-service sports agency representing professional athletes, leagues and teams in all aspects of marketing opportunities. Tom is also a partner in XSM Global, an action sports agency, and Mint Farm Films, a documentary production company focusing on hall of fame level athletes.

Tom was one of the first employees of the Dallas Stars Hockey Club after its relocation from Minnesota. Helping hockey get its foothold in the Lone Star State over 14 years, the last four serving as Executive Vice President of Corporate Sales, he was responsible for all team sponsorship sales. For three of those years he simultaneously wore a similar hat with the Texas Rangers Major League Baseball Club as Vice President of Sponsorships when the front offices of the two teams were merged.

Tom served on the board of directors of the Dallas Stars Foundation and is currently Vice President of the Mike Modano Foundation and a board member of the Tribute to Valor Foundation.

Darwin J. Bruce is a business leader, author, speaker, and corporate lawyer with Haynes and Boone LLP. Darwin has extensive domestic and international experience in business organization, strategic planning, operations, and mergers and acquisitions. Darwin has been featured in D CEO Magazine in a profile about lead executives operating non-profit companies. His publications include the book “The Map to Entrepreneurship.”

Darwin has served as the chief operating officer for T.D. Jakes Ministries where he was responsible for managing all business affairs for the organization and its affiliated entities. He has served as chief executive officer for an electronics manufacturing and service company. He has also served as a senior vice president and general counsel for a healthcare finance company and private equity company.

Lo Andrews is a former NBA draft pick of the Kansas City Kings and a graduate of Oklahoma State University. Lo is senior vice president of Treasury & Liquidity Solutions for Texas Capital Bank. In this role, he is responsible for Texas Capital’s sales and business development strategy for the treasury and liquidity solutions group marketed toward corporate businesses in the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex and nationally. As national sales executive, Lo also manages and leads the sales efforts for Texas Capital Bank’s Fiduciaries & Bankruptcy Trustees business, serving the bankruptcy industry and Specialty Deposit Services business, serving the capital markets industry.

Andrews joined Texas Capital Bank’s Treasury & Liquidity Executive Team in November of 2011 after twenty one years with JPMorgan Chase where he worked in a variety of senior leadership sales roles in the Global Treasury Services (GTS), based in Dallas, Texas. He joined Bank One in July of 1990 as a Vice President and Sales Manager in Treasury Management and, prior to Bank One, he began his banking career as a credit analyst with First City Bank Texas.

Lo’s Board involvement, in addition to the NBRPA Dallas Chapter, includes HOPE Farm, Micaela’s Army Foundation, Oak Cliff Christian Federal Credit Union and Don’t Ask Why.

Carter Keith is a founder and CEO of the 31,000 FT advertising agency. He started his career at Leo Burnett in media and account service training. After a stint on P&G, he was shipped off to the Athens Greece office. After 8 years with Burnett, he moved to the Bloom agency which was later acquired by Publicis. Over 22 years, he worked on a variety of blue chip accounts such as Nestle, GSK, Abbott Labs, and Zale’s. He launched 31K in 2012. Clients include Gold Bond, Icy Hot, ACT, Epson Printers, Milo’s Tea, Acuity Eyecare and more. In addition to the NBRPA Dallas Chapter, he also sits on the board of Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

A proven hospitality executive with over 40 years of experience, Bill has been successful in leading hotel/resort properties to award levels for exceptional performance of guest services, along with delivering solid financial results. He has mentored and promoted over 32 executive committee members to the next level in the past 20 years. Bill was awarded General Manager & Hotel of The Year by John Q. Hammons Hotel & Resort Company and the Remington Hotel Company.

He received the AHLA highest certification of “Certified Hotel Administrator” for over 20 consecutive years. Bill is a graduate of The University of Oklahoma with a BBA in Management. He has a passion for helping others to accomplish far beyond their own imagination in what they thought they were capable to achieve.
